description:
Spizellomyces punctatus DAOM BR117 is a species of chytrid fungus that belongs to the phylum Chytridiomycota. Chytrids are a group of aquatic fungi known for their distinctive zoospores, which are the motile, flagellated reproductive cells.

S. punctatus DAOM BR117 is a saprobic species, meaning it derives its nutrients from dead or decaying organic matter in the environment. It is commonly found in soil and freshwater habitats, where it plays a role in the decomposition of plant and animal materials.

Morphologically, S. punctatus DAOM BR117 is characterized by its spherical or ellipsoidal sporangia (reproductive structures) that are typically 10-20 Î¼m in diameter. The sporangia produce multiple, uniflagellated zoospores, which are the primary means of dispersal and reproduction for this fungus.

Taxonomically, S. punctatus DAOM BR117 is classified within the genus Spizellomyces, which is a group of chytrids known for their unique development and zoospore characteristics. The "DAOM BR117" designation refers to the specific strain or isolate that has been deposited in the culture collection of the Canadian Department of Agriculture (DAOM).
